thread.title: For the love of her late mother and baseball, this Texas woman visited every MLB ballpark
thread.title_full: For the love of her late mother and baseball, this Texas woman visited every MLB ballpark - San Antonio Express-News

author: Madalyn Mendoza
title: For the love of her late mother and baseball, this Texas woman visited every MLB ballpark
text:

Photo: Mendoza, Madalyn S, Provided By Katie Russell Image 31 of 31 For the love of her late mother and baseball, this Texas woman visited every MLB ballpark 1 / 31 Back to Gallery The unbreakable mother-daughter bond paired with the love of America’s pastime led one Texas woman on a journey across the country to visit every Major League Baseball stadium in the United States.
Katie Russell, a 38-year-old Trinity University alumna, said in an interview with mySA.com that baseball is something that she and her late mother spent years bonding over. After losing her mom to cancer in 2009 and enduring her own battle against the disease, she decided to do something in honor of their relationship.
She said their love of the game started simply when she was a child – they lived in New Orleans without a sports team to follow but they became fans of the Chicago Cubs since their games were televised.
The hobby eventually transformed into a relentless passion for Russell as she became a softball player herself throughout her years as a student.
“My mom loved to travel, and she loved baseball,” she said. “Going to see all the ballparks made for the perfect combination of those two loves. We decided we wanted to visit all the MLB ballparks after we went to Wrigley Field for the first time.
RELATED: This New Yorker took his terminally ill dog on an awesome bucket list trip with stops in San Antonio
With her own love for travel, baseball and her mother, Russell began her 6-month "MLB for Mom" journey on April 6, 2015 in Philadelphia, where her mother’s family is from.
“It was opening day for the Philadelphia Phillies, and it was also my mom’s birthday,” she added. “I couldn’t think of a better gift for her then to begin the journey we had always wanted to complete.”
From April to September, the dedicated daughter left her mark at every ballpark in the United States – especially at Wrigley Field where she was able to throw the ceremonial first pitch for her favorite team.
“It was AMAZING! I think Wrigley and the Chicago Cubs are the ultimate symbol in baseball for hope and what it means to endure,” she said. “Although this was a childhood dream of mine to throw out the first pitch, I was throwing it out for more than just myself.”
People who had lost someone to cancer, of girls with baseball dreams, underdogs and mother-daughter duos were all on her mind as she stepped onto the field, she added.
Russell said she’s still learning from her mom, years after her passing.
“[…] I was able to uncover some of the larger narratives that baseball evokes about life and some of the things my mom was always trying to teach me growing up: living life to the fullest, following your dreams, maintaining a sense of adventure and curiosity about life, never giving up hope and supporting the underdog,” she said.
Now that her cross-country journey is complete, she’s working on another project tied to her love for her mother and the sport they loved. Pass Christian, Miss. is the place where she spent some childhood years, where her mother’s ashes were spread and where Hurricane Katrina wreaked havoc years ago. Some things, like a fence around a local baseball team’s field, have gone unrepaired. With a GoFundMe campaign , Russell is hoping to fix that and give back to the baseball community that has shaped her.
“In the end, I have had the chance to honor my mom’s life and dream, and I think she would be really proud of me,” she said.
mmendoza@mysa.com
Twitter: @MaddySkye
